This is a priority of mine; it’s why unlike most offices, we have more people in New Jersey than in Washington, because making an impact in the lives of our neighbors is the most important thing.
Whether it’s helping seniors access their Medicare benefits or veterans get their lost medals, our casework staff work tirelessly for our communities.

Some of my proudest moments of the last year don’t have anything to do with legislation in Washington, but the people our office has been able to help in New Jersey. These were all bipartisan efforts and I'll keep working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to advocate for Burlington and Ocean Counties and make sure your priorities get the support they deserve.
And we've sadly seen opioid addiction and veteran suicide on the rise, so I worked across the aisle to deliver programs to help address both.

We've struggled this year with flooding, so I made sure our small businesses have more money for disaster recovery. Our communities have struggled with clean drinking water, so I made sure $1.45 billion in funding will go towards new safe drinking water infrastructure.

Earlier today, the House voted to fund the government for this Fiscal Year. While we made progress last week, the fight isn't over yet. I'll continue to work with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to get the job done and make an impact for those struggling to pay for their prescription drugs.

I also heard from Dorothy, a Burlington County SHIP counselor who works with people every day to help them afford care. The people I heard from are a small sample of the hundreds of thousands in our state who struggle every day to make ends meet while paying for their medicine.
One of those people was LeNor LeDoux. She lives in Burlington and had to file for bankruptcy because of the high costs of her prescription drugs.

Last week's fight to #LowerDrugCosts wasn't about passing a bill, it was about making an impact in people's lives. Yesterday, I sat down with some of our neighbors who need Congress to take action on the cost of prescription drugs. https://www.burlingtoncountytimes.com/news/20191216/kim-fight-to-lower-prescription-drug-prices-continues …

We're continuing our work to make sure you have a voice in this process. If you live in Ocean County and have questions about this issue, you can email my team at Kim.OysterCreek2@mail.house.gov. We're here to answer your questions and make sure you're heard.
Earlier this year, I held a town hall on the process. People in the community brought questions and I brought experts to provide answers. But the work isn't done there.

Earlier this week I spoke with @NewJerseyDEP Commissioner McCabe about the current decommissioning process at Oyster Creek in Ocean County. This is an issue I hear about a lot, and my team has been working on intensely. pic.twitter.com/vSBUb3p7jL
I hope they'll join me in voting for this bill to #LowerDrugCosts. I'm doing it for John and Vicki. And I'm not going to stop until we get the job done.

Next month, I'll hold another town hall, and I know I'll hear more stories like this. My colleagues will do the same. By acting today, we can tell them that we've taken action. That we've helped ensure they'll never have to make these horrific choices.

Another is Vicki, a 58 year old from Toms River who suffers from Crohn's and spends $1500 a month on her medication. She has to choose between medicine or saving for a retirement. That's not a choice anyone should have to make.

One example is John, a 75 year old from Berkeley who suffers from COPD and asthma. He needs an inhaler to breathe, but barely has the $250 a month to pay for it. John often faces a choice: he can breathe or he can eat. That’s not a choice anyone should have to make.

Over the past year, I’ve held fifteen town halls in those two counties. And at every single one of them, I’ve heard from Democrats and Republicans about the need to lower the cost of prescription drugs. They don't want excuses, they want help.

Later today, I'm going to vote to pass H.R. 3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, which would allow Medicare to negotiate lower drug prices so our seniors can afford the medicine they depend on. Let me tell you why. (thread) pic.twitter.com/bRPzle1lsI
